message.content: This question requires knowledge about the rotation of planets and the concept of day and night. When a planet rotates, it causes cycles of day and night as different parts of the planet are exposed to the sun's light. Option (A) is incorrect because Orion is not a planet, it is a constellation. Option (B) is also incorrect because the Moon experiences phases of day and night due to its orbit around the Earth, not its rotation. Option (D) is incorrect because Pluto has a highly inclined and eccentric orbit, resulting in irregular and long periods of daylight and darkness. Only option (C), Jupiter, is a planet that rotates and experiences cycles of day and night.

This question requires basic knowledge about the rotation of celestial bodies. When a planet rotates, it causes cycles of day and night. Option (C) is the correct answer because Jupiter, like Earth, rotates on its axis, causing cycles of day and night. Option (A) is incorrect because Orion is a constellation and not a planet. Option (B) is incorrect because the Moon does not rotate on its axis, so it experiences a "tidal lock" with Earth, where one side always faces us, causing the same side to always be in daylight and the other side always in darkness. Option (D) is incorrect because Pluto, although it rotates, has a highly elliptical and tilted orbit, causing irregular patterns of daylight and darkness on its surface.

Option (B) is incorrect because the Moon does not rotate on its axis in a way that causes day and night cycles like on Earth. Option (D) is incorrect because Pluto is no longer considered a planet. Option (C), Jupiter, is a planet that rotates on its axis and causes cycles of day and night.
